element_texts.text:
we could get across the noll? without difficulty. The conductor tells me that there has been no connection for a month, so I paid our way to Kansas city, & we went to bed. 

  Friday December 12, 79. Was waked up at 5 am by the porter, we had been in Kansas City two or more hours. We got up & about 6 am had breakfast. About 7 we took the train for Leavenworth, where we arrived early & went to the Planters House. I went out & did a lot of

the Boy. He is so loving & affectionate - so much the tender boy with all his genius?, that I find my heart very full of him. It was a hard struggle to give him up, & my eyes filled with tears when he repeatedly turned back to dance along the track on which he was walking & yell & signal to us. Very soon we were hitched? out by our Engine & were speeding towards Leavenworth. The agent at the Depot assured us

Spent the day there &
bought all I want for this
trip. Came back loaded
with bundles etc. . Spent
the evening? {receiving?} visits
Sunday Dec 14. 79.
Went to Popes Sunday School
met all the Officers & had 
"Chin" ad lib. Very
pleasant morning. Julia 
went to Church- Spent the
evening visiting. Returned 
all my calls & had a nice 
time. 
Monday Dec 15  79-
Julia & I went down early 
to 11worth.- for I was to take
the cars & start for my

work. Julia remained in her room resting until after 12 oclk dinner when she went out shopping & to hunt up unclear. About 3 pm Lt Dodge came with an ambulance & carried us both off to Ft llworth to his house where we were made as happy & comfortable as possible. 

 Had another driver & paid a lot of bills -

Saturday Dec 13, 79.
Went down town early first visiting Genl Pope

could be & at 4.15
pm started for Kansas
City- where we arrived
ab 5.30. Stopped at the 
R.R. House. Had a 
good supper. Excellent 
room & every comfort.
[uncleal) joined us at the 
Leavenworth City Depot

 We had a real old eve-

ring of comfort. Tooty
scrubbed my head & we
were all day happy. 
I have never seen Julia
more happy & more loathe 
to give me up. She
has cordially a new care.

post. We arrived at Depot waited & waited. The train by which I expected to catch the A.T.&S.F. R.R was not even made up. So wofully annoyed we made some few purchases & returned to the Fort.

 We had made up our minds to go to Kansas City on the evening train. Stay there over night & start from there tomorrow.
 We had a pleasant day with the Dodges who have been as kind & hospitable as any people

Up early & to see Hardenbrook about conveyance. He had promised to take me through to Pond Creek with a relay at Caldwell in one day for $10. He sent the relay down to Caldwell but finding passengers there it came back same day.

 After considerable trouble the conveyance came - with 2 mules hitched in front - 2 horses tied to the back -
 The horses were to be my relay
 Got off at 9 am & got to Caldwell nicely by 1 pm. Got drivers & the "rig" came for me

Tuesday Dec 16. 79

 I got off at 10 am leaving Julia & unclear They will remain at the hotel & go to Rock Island tonight -- It was hard to part with the dear "Old Lady" but I am tough 
 Long tedious ride. Dinner at Topeka supper at Florence Change cars at Newton & arrive at Wellington 12 at night. Went to see about conveyance tomorro but got little satisfaction 
 To bed at 1 am --
 Wednesday Dec 17

wanted to stop. I know all the tricks of alkali & assured him that his only chance of saving the horse was to keep him going

 However the fellow at last pulled up in spite of me & the horse almost immediately laid down
 We got him out of the harness. He got up staggered around a moment & fell dead. We made the other animal as pack horse piling all the things on him & trudged into Pond Creek where we arrived at

with the horses hitched in?

 It was very hard on them but "twas none of my funeral" & I said nothing
 At "pole cat" station about half way, one of the horses showed symptoms of illness 
 Hard driving alkali 
 water & a feed of corn.  
 However it was so slight that the driver after bleeding the horse he started again.
 We went on nicely for some time but the horse was evidently growing worse
 On & on we went. The driver was frightened &

Friday 19th

 Hoped to have got some Turkeys last night but was too tired. It has been quite cold. Had to make something more of a march than I intended yesterday as we found the grass burned where I wanted to camp.
 Got off 830 am & arrived at post without accident at 1 pm.
 Found everything going on well. Joe much better in health -
 All serene - Am glad to get The Comfort of home

7 O clk at night having walked 4 miles in the dark

 Found my party with ambulance etc. tent pitched, bed made & after a good supper I turned in & slept all the better for the mishaps of the day.
 Thursday 18 Dec
 Got off at 9 am.
 Paid my driver $12 for conveyance & $1 for himself. Wrote to Julia a short note - started off lighthearted with good teams - all night - Camped on Walnut Creek --

Jany 21st 1880
Clarke & I started on a trip to see if any game is left in the country. Left Post about 10 am with a nice escort & all comfortable. Turned our heads South West towards the Canadian a country we have not before hunted in /

 Travelled about 15 miles mostly across burnt ground seeing nothing to shoot as Went into camp about 4 pm on a pretty little tributary of Canadian - remained

Spent a month at home with varying comforts & pleasures
 The days go by so fast I can scarcely keep account of them.
 Have put up ice made every body comfortable  - renovated & refitted my own house
 built me a stable & now that the work is all done I take a play day for a week preparatory to real military work - which I commence 1st Feby.

me. So I gave my gun to Boon - Clarke is now out down the Creek & Boon up. They have been gone an hour & there has been no shot

 Routz on my striker left my cartridges so I sent an Indian back after them, & will wait tomorrow until they arrive
 I ought to get something tomorro morning - for there is plenty of sign of game.

on the maps - Excellent water wood & grass - The sandy bed of the creek was marked in every direction with Turkey & our tracks - but though Clarke & I went through beautiful woods looking for a roost we found no sign of where any Turkey had roosted.

 Came back & sent Boone up the creek on same errand. He came back just at dark having found no sign of a roost - This discouraged

gone down the creek & saw nothing. Told him about the roost & we planned a campaign. Nap in afternoon We started out after dark rode 4 miles to the roost & had the satisfaction of hearing a hundred turkeys go off the roost unclear on ever getting a shot --

 Have never seen birds so wild - My cartridge came all right - Shot a squirrels head off with rifle My bag 2 Turkeys 1 squirrel Total 3 Turkeys 1 squirrel

Jany 22d 1880
Clarke came in about 11 last night with a magnificent gobbler 20 lbs at least  Only one he got a shot at. Saw but 3 -- I started out about 8 this am - worked hard found a large roost & came upon a drove of some 50 turkeys - Got only 2. Though I am sure I mortally wounded several more. Got back to camp about 12 m - Clarke had

Followed Jeb's trail for about 10 miles, where it turned upon the high dry divide. Left it & pulled off to the North East. Camped on a small branch near unclear. No sign of game of any kind. Fanny my Setter Bitch distinguished herself today finding several bunches of grouse prairie chickens They were however very wild & it was very difficult to get near them. I managed to bag 2 one at nearly 80 yards off with a No 2 wire cartridge

Jany 23d 80
Broke camp at 8.30 
Took Tebigess? trail hoping to come to some good hunting ground. Crossed Canadian near mouth of Creek, & on south side found another beautiful Creek - plenty of water & well timbered, but no game. Soon discovered the reason in an abandoned Indian Camp only ten days or 2 weeks old - The very same ruffians who spooked our hunters on the other side of the river

Jany 23rd 1880
Rainy during night & this a.m. Did'nt like looks of clouds & in spite of rain moved camp across Canadian

 The bed is almost dry now & it is easy to cross anywhere but a few inches of water changes it to one of the most difficult & dangerous of stream.
 Came north & camped on a lovely little stream far up in the hills - Clarke & I walked up to look for a Turkey roost - We found a splendid one but we found also the camp search a week old of that infernal batch of Indians

Clarke was in specially bad luck & got nothing. The water we are on is very alkali & we have rather a poor camp -
Tomorro I shall pull across the river & try our luck on that side - There is nothing here. In fact the country is unclear of game by the Indians -- We have been today through perfectly lovely hunting grounds -- & found nothing 

 Disposed to rain tonight.
 Beat Clark badly at Cribbage
 Total bag - 3 Turkeys 1 squirrel 2 grouse - Sent Turkeys to post.

Jany 25th 1880
Started about 9 am
Clark went off to the west to hunt the creek he failed to find last night - I had to remain with the wagons as we anticipated serious work getting through the Black Jacks Boon & I differed as to the best chance for getting through but though he had been well up on the north he proposed to take. I did'nt like it & took my own way -- Result a perfect success -- found a most excellent route & got through the Blackjack

whose traces we seem destined not to escape from - We have passed 3 of their camps & they have cleared the country of game

 They must have killed 50 deer in this camp judging from the hair. We got nothing of course. except 4 quail from a small covey that came into camp in evening. Clarke Boon & Monahan went out after dark to try to find a roost on a creek further west -- but came back empty 
 Beat Clark again at cribbage - My bag today 3 quail Total bag - 3 Turkeys 1 squirrel 2 grouse 4 quail --

blessed in having it. I am now camped on the head of Deep Creek in country that Monahan said, two days ago -was utterly impossible for wagons. Yet I came in today without the use of axe or spade - & shall go out tomorro just as easily - I guess its knowledge - for luck would not always stick to me. 

 My teamsters almost believe I am a wizard for as the proper moment when the route in front seems absolutely

without cutting a branch. I am certainly wonderfully successful in finding routes, & in taking wagons across country - It is of course experience & knowledge to some extent - but if I were asked why I took the route I did today I could only answer that I thought it would prove the best - I could give no reason beyond what might be a mere instinct. I believe the success comes from knowledge or mere luck - I am greatly

Our cook this morning told me he was out of fresh meat - so I was hunting for dinner & breakfast tomorro - 

 Clarke hunted all day but got nothing.
 Boon went out after deer but saw nothing but a Bear track. There is no game in the country 
 Cold disagreeable south wind all day - It is getting monotonous
 My bag 1 grouse 5 quail 
 Total - 3 Turkeys - 3 grouse - 9 quail - 1 squirrel 1 robin

impracticable. I gallop ahead & in a few moments return to conduct the wagons through an easy gap, & all goes smooth again.

 The dogs found a fine covey of grouse, but they were wild as hawks. I got only one. Saw a good many deer tracks in the Black jacks, but all old -- After I got into Camp I walked down the creek for half a mile found a covey of quail & got (5) five. I also murdered a robin.

ought to be 5 miles below us but which was above. I recognized the situation at once. We had not camped on the head of Deep Creek but on a more easterly stream Crossed the river. Struck the road, & the trail of our wagons & arrived again at the river to find the 6 mule team stuck in quick sand. Worked at them a little while & got them out. Had a few good chances at grouse. Bagged one early in the day. a very long shot my bitch came to a dead point on

Jany 26th 1880
Directed my party to go from fish pond opposite the mouth of Deep Creek & go into camp - Clarke & I went off across country & crossed river about 2 miles above mouth of Creek & west downward. When we got to the place where we ought to have found our pond it was not there. Clarke insisted  that it was below, & I thought so also, but before deciding I mounted a Sand Hill & looked all about. At last I discovered what I believed to be Cottonwood grove - which

I am sure he could'nt have bagged three at his distance for they were further from him than the others were & he was on my right.

 I am very sure I bagged birds but I allowed him one by counting. After he got in camp tried fishing but got no bite -  A good many ducks came around but were very wild & we got no shot --
 played Crib at night. Clark beat me 3 games in 30 --
 My bag 5 grouse 1 quail I claim - Total bag 3 turkeys. 8 grouse  10 quail - 1 squirrel 1 robin

the trail above Deep creek

 I got down & walked towards her. At about 60 yds off two grouse got up & went off leisurely. I waited till they got together & brought them both down with a single shot. Soon after we found a covey of 5 birds which got up a long way off, but I took it coolly being loaded with wire cartridges.
 When the two left birds got together I fired & both fell.
 To my great surprise Clarke claimed three,

lying, when a turkey got up before her & then another. If I had been properly loaded & prepared I could have got both --
D____ing ----
Found ambulance, put dogs in - got in ourselves & reached post about 4 pm. Letter from Sis Anne Mother & Father safe in Rockingham.
Splendid notices of Fred
My bag of trip - 2 Turkeys 8 grouse - 18 quail - 1 squirrel 1 robin - Clarke 1 Turkey 5 quail
Total 3 Turkeys - 8 grouse 23 quail 1 squirrel 1 robin

Jany 27 - Tuesday - 1880.

 Our luck has been so poor that I determined to go to the post today. unclear Boon to wait for me at my duck pond near Sheridans roost -- Clarke & I went through the Sand Hills
 Found 2 coveys of quail 
 I bagged 9, & he 4. I am now satisfied that I can beat him shooting 2 to 1. Bitch came to a point, but the place was so unfavorable for quail that I rode up to her & accused her of

Thursday Feby 19, 1880
Very cold last night. The pond froze & the ducks that were in had to seek other quarters. Randal & I got on our horses about 7 am & took to the sand hills - 

 Nothing rewarded our labors until we got near my favorite fish pond where we discovered a small flock of Turkeys - 
 I put after them as fast as old Baxter could go through the sand. Soon one got up before me & I bagged him neatly. After some hunting I flushed another & broke

Feby 18th 1880 --
This time I took Randall with me - Got off about 9 am - Kept to ambulance until near Sheridan Roost then took to our horses.  At a favorite duck pond 4 Mallards got up They were so far that I had no hope but I let fly - to my delight one fell - so I let off the other barrel & got another - It was too far for Jake & his gun.

 Bagged 2 birds of a kind new to me - a species of Jay I think
 Camped at Cottonwood grove plenty of water & good camp 
 Bag - 2 Mallards -

swim to perfection. I laughed till my ribs were sore at Jake He is not much of a shot & requires deliberation. A duck would pop up. Jake take deliberate aim & by the time his shot got to the duck he was safe under water again.

 He must have fired a dozen times before he succeeded in killing unclear. Just before we got to camp we came on a splendid drove of Turkeys at least fifty - They were not very wild & would not fly but they managed themselves so well that I could not get a shot -- I might have

his wing. My orderly Carter & I had a lively chase & I had to shoot him again

 Randall got a couple of good shots, but his horse unclear him. We then went to my pond a fine flock of ducks got up at long range & I got 2 right & left - One long tail & one unclear
 Found several nice ponds but it is rather too early for the ducks - One had a fine flock of shell drakes. I knocked down two & set Randall to killing them. They were wounded so they could not fly but they could dive &

Friday Feby 20
Bad Medicine today -

 None of the hunters found a roost last night, so nothing added to the bag.
The morning was wretched rain & very windy. Hunters everywhere but could not find Evers old trail
 Had to strike out on my own hook. Struck head of main branch of Evers Creek, crossed its dry bed & there took the divide between that & a Creek to the west hoping to get down between them

done so by dashing up on old Burke but the chance of bagging was so small that I preferred parting for tonight. 

 Camped at Osage Springs.
 Excellent camping place. Sent Boon out to hunt a coot, but he came back at dark without having found one.
 Today has been very delightful bracing, almost cold, & tho we did'nt kill much we had fine fun -

Bag today -

 2 turkeys - 1 Long tail duck 1 med grouse 2 shell drake
 I shot unremarkably well & my gun outdid itself.

with difficulty from which we would have to extricate ourselves tomorrow -

 Camped on main branch of Evers Creek - just where the water begins. All this Country is Gypsum formation & the water horrible - we brought own from Osage Sp. Plenty of deer, but though I walked myself almost to death, I saw nothing but tracks. Bears & panthers also plenty. No sign of Turkey. I find no shot today. Several shots were had at deer by the men
 Not a thing bagged

The divide is high & the branches on each side interlace, in Canon fifty to 100 feet deep & perpendicular We got through the rather bad places by the skin of our teeth, but quickly came to one, where the Cañons overlapped & ran together so as to make one canon 100 feet deep - so we had to turn back. To our right as we came I had noticed an apparently good lateral divide - Went back to it - & got along very well knowing of course that we were getting

of fresh tracks of deer but the animals themselves kept well away -- After a while the Canon became so bad, that I feared my Indian might get the wagons into serious difficulty -- So I went to them just in time - got them over a terribly bad place.

 Its an awfully broken country. Almost as bad as the Black Hills & more because it fools you at the time - To stand on a high divide & look even an experienced

Saturday Feby 21, 80
One of my Indian Scouts - Buffalo - joined us last night - to my delight for I am tired of playing guide when I want to hunt.

 This morning I started him out with the wagons while I went down the creek hunting. The gorge was so narrow & the thicket so dense that we had great difficulty in getting through, & made so much noise that all the game was scared off before we could see it -- I saw plenty

a straight line - but we have travelled more than 15 

 It took us 6 mortal hours & only about 20 minutes of that in work --
 I got after a swale covey of quail, which were in a canon 100 feet deep, & not so wide.
 I killed 3 birds in 3 shots but could not find one. 
 I was well satisfied to get 2 for I had no dog & even had he been along he could have done nothing. I got in with difficulty & had to chop? a tree to get out. Buffalo & Boon each got a Jack Rabbit

plainsman would say "I can go so & so" but when he tries it he cant Like all other countries it is cut & scored in every direction by water ways --

 These being flush with the general level do not show but when you get to them they are nasty ditches 50 to 200 feet wide & as many deep - with banks straight up & down May of them cannot be crossed even on horseback & wagons have to head them. We have we have made today not over 8 miles in

Sunday Feby 22, 80 --
Had the only good shot at a deer that I had had since the Winter Campaign of 1876. I plastered him all over with Buck shot, so that it only ran a few hundred yards & laid down --

 This it kept doing, my luck being always to be a long way off when it got up & none of the others could hit it 
 Followed it over two miles through the sand hills by tracks & blood

Near the mouth of Evers Creek came to a cattle Ranch.

 They say that hundreds of hunters have been in the Country & almost all the game is killed or run out -- Buffalo brought in across the Cimarron to a Turkey roost he knew of but on examination we find that the Turkeys have all been run off.
 So no game today --
 A splendid day & I have enjoyed every moment 
 Camped North of Cimarron

Monday Feby 23, 1880
Another lovely day.
Got a long shot about 100 yds - at ducks & killed 3 -- Wire cartridges

 Got safely across the Cimarron - I always have a certain uneasy feeling when I am on that moving side of that abominable bed of sand & a comparably? feeling of relief when on the right side 
 Found two small coveys of grouse of which I bagged

find at it five times hit it every time & yet it got away. It was covered with blood & in undoubtedly dead now but I did nt bag it

 Killed one rabbitt one grouse & 2 ducks 
 Had a long hard journey 25 miles of sand --
 Camped on Eagle Chief Buffalo says he will show me some Turkeys tomorro --
 Tried fishing but got no fish -- Lovely Day but a bit too warm

regular roost, & that if Buffalo found them here very plenty it was because they had been driven from better roosts -

 The timber is too small - & much scattered & the ravines in which they are, are almost unpassable in daylight 
 I took a turn of about a mile satisfied myself that I had no use for any such hunting -- Shot at & wounded a solitary old gobbler - which however got away

4. Randall 1 - Buffalo got a Jack Rabbitt almost as big as a calf -- I think the largest I ever saw --

 Went into camp on the edge of the Black Jacks about 2 pm Buffalo found & fired at a flock of Turkeys.
 I ordered all shooting stopped til night
 I went out on foot to examine this great coast. & very soon satisfied myself that it is not a

Tuesday Feby 24 _ 80 _
Nothing. got in about 10 am __
Dear Father died __

& came back to camp disgusted.

 Let all the would be hunters go out at night lending one my gun All came back in an hour or two played out & disgusted -- Turkeys are here but so well protected by the nature of the ground, that even Buffalo came back without one --
 We are within 10 or 12 miles of the post 
 We try one grand effort tomorro ---

Thursday Mch 25, 80
My diary has lost its interest in a great measure since dear Father's death - since much that I wrote about - particularly hunting & fishing was for his enjoyment.

 Last mail I received a letter from Ford telling me that he & his Mother would be in Leavenworth on 1st April -- I telegraphed words smudged Pope for leave 
 got 20 days & started

Friday Mch 26
Up about 4 am Roused Randall. Had breakfast by candle light. Randall & I parted at sun rise 

 Road pretty good. Boon an excellent driver.
 Thousands of brown places on the prairie & saw Curlew. Bagged 1 chicken & 8 plover - Arrived at Pond Ck 2.50 pm

42 miles in 8 hours 20 m
Escort wagons got in about 5 pm. Hail & rain storm - tired went to bed early -

this morning after getting everything at the post in excellent order --

 At Walnut Ck found Randall in camp & camped with him tho I wanted to go further
 He is on his way to take Comd of Ft Reno _ His compy has been detached from my port entirely
 He gives me good hope of my getting an expedition this summer.
 We gassed till 10 pm then went to bed.
 Got 1 duck redhead
 24 miles

of one side of my tent. Ten feet more to the west would have saved any more writing in this diary & given promotion to somebody --

 I did not even hear it fall 
 the general commotion outside & inside preventing my noticing any special sound --
 Very cold & blustery this am
 Got off at 8 am -- & arrived at Pardus camp at 1 pm.
 tired cold & disgusted --
 Found all right in camp.
 The men have settled down after their grand spree with 4 mos pay to spend & all seems to be in good shape

Saturday Mch 27, 1880
A furious wind storm all night with occasional rain.

 Soon after I got to bed I had to call the sentinel & have my tent secured. He told me that a tree had just been blown down across one of the tents of the men. He had heard it cracking & got them out in time.
 I dont think I was ever in a more furious wind storm but I finally went to bed & to sleep
 This morning when I came out I was not a little surprised to find a large branch of a tree lying on the tent cords

Sunday 28, Mch -
Left my baggage wagon at Paeden Camp, & with Boon & ambulance went for Wellington, making the distance 24 miles in 3 hours 10 minutes

 Soon found Heinicke & got every thing ready for taking back - {seeds I mean).
 Stopped at _________ Hotel - All the hotel poor - Spent the evening with Heineki & wife.
 Monday 29 Mch
 Took train 3.40 am - & arrived at Kansas City without delay or accident 6 in afternoon
 Found the Company at the

After dinner I went up to Caldwell to see if I could find some onion sets etc.
Nothing to be had - spent a quiet evening with the boys - 
The prairie today was covered as I never before saw it with wild fowl. Thousands of brown plover. Some few field plover. Curlew, Kindur? ducks, prairie chickens --

 Had it been a decent day I could have bagged a load but twas so cold & windy that I did not hunt - shot two or three times at antelope at long distances & running

Tuesday 30th March.
Spent the day pleasantly with Fred loafing about shopping etc

 At night he played Shylock. It was only his second appearance in the part but his acting was most marvelous.
 Wednesday 31st March
 All went up to Leavenworth Fred & I went out to post & installed ourselves with the Dodge's both of whom were delighted to see us.  Went to see the General & had a good time with my friends.
 Lady of Lyons at night
 A large party at the post

Clk's House but to my great disgust the Clerk told me as I registered that "Mrs Dodge is not with them" --

 Went up to Fred's room found him with a bad cold, but otherwise well - sitting in a cold room writing (found out afterwards that he is essaying a novel) He was delighted to see me - for he was by no means sure I could come to visit them
 Julia was left behind sick having been over come with heat in New Orleans --
 He played Hamlet delightfully in the evening. He has very greatly improved

before Julia arrived -- She had been sick with rush of blood to the head in New Orleans & went to Macon Georgia to recuperate - While there an old sweetheart Monroe Ogden found her out & made her time very agreeable. He is married & living there. 

 She had a series of adventures & wound up by losing her most valuable trunk -- She is very well now & happy to get back to cool weather - A delightful evening - visitors keeping aloof Left Minty? in town with her mother

but nearly all our friends went to City & saw Fred play before going to it. Fred & Mrs Dodge went & had a good time 

 I went to bed.

Thursday April 1 -

 Telegram from Julia yesterday. She will be here tomorro. Had a good time all around. visited city & did some shopping. Shylock at night
 Friday April 2

All the post wild over Fred's Shylock. The Company went to Topeka this am - I remain behind. Fred had not been gone an hour

Monday April 5
Left at 10.45 am - all hands of us & "unclear the show" again.
Went to Atchison. Miserable hotel poor house at night 
Lady of Lyons -

 Tuesday April 6

Went to Lincoln. Good hotel 
Lined out: Took Julia out riding in a buggy. Beautiful country

 Hamlet at night to a poor house.
 Wednesday April 7
 Took Julia out buggy riding - Beautiful country & lovely day - Enjoyed ourselves
 Fools Revenge to a not very good house - Telegraphed

Saturday April 3d -
Went down town with Julia on a trunk hunting expedition. Drew my pay for March & made many purchases - We got back just before dinner.

 Lots of visitors in evening --
 Sunday April 4th

Julia & Mrs D. went to Church & I went to Popes Sunday School where I met nearly all the higher Offs of the post. Fred arrived about noon. All of us went to Mrs Dunnes? to Tea & had a delightful evening - Fred had poor houses in Topeka.

accommodations abominable - All of us glad to get to Des Moines at 1 pm. Got dinner at once - Went to Kirkwood House, a very fair hotel - played Romeo to Miss Eldriges Juliet. I forgot to say in the proper place that Miss Gussie DeForest has left the Compy & Miss Eldridge taken her place. The latter joined us at Atchison. She is very pretty but too large for Fred & not to my thinking as good an actress as Gussie - Fred's Romeo is  beautiful.

Lined out: Thursd to Genl Pope asking him to extend my leave five days --
Thursday April 8
Reached Omaha 6 pm. Found telegram extending my leave -

 Several friends called. Mrs Crook among them. Shylock at night to a good House.

Friday April 9th
Had to start at 5 am. Hard work getting up but Julia has gotten so she can "make an effort" when necessary.

No breakfast - Miserable abortion of an eatery house at Spoon Lake - & all

Sunday April 11
Lovely day. Took a long walk. Julia went to Church

 Fred played at night to a good house -

Monday Apl 12
Went to Rock Island. Fred well received. Shylock.
April 13
Compy went on. Julia & I remained. Intended to go to unclear but was so windy that we staid at home. I left her in the afternoon for Kansas City
Apl 14
Arrived Kansas City - late

Saturday April 10th
Blustery day - Matinee. Claude Melnotte - Evening, Shylock to good houses. Fred is well received in Des Moines, & is urged to play in Hamlet tomorro night. He played two Sundays in New Orleans but this is the first northern city where he has been asked to play on that day. Being a good Catholic he has no scruples about it & Hd man Loveday announced the performance for tomorro between the acts tonight - Supper at night with Julia & Fred at a nice Restaurant

Big Creek
May 7th 1880
When I was in 11worth Genl Pope told me that there was a possibility of my taking the field against the Utes in Comd of 15 Cos --

 The possibility was so remote that I scarcely allowed my self to hope --
 Today it is a fixed fact & I am in Comd of 3 Cos of my Regt. en route for Fort Garland - 
 Ten days ago I got a letter from Dep Hodges repeating the possibility -
 Then we heard that 2

Ran into a car on side track. woke every body up but me. Delayed us 2 hours. The A.T. & S. F Train had waited for us. So nothing was lost.  Arrived Wellington midnight
Apl 15. Ambulance & escort waiting. Started 8.30 Arrived Pardes? Camp 12.30 - lunched got my own team - & arrived Pond Ck in good time - 16th camped on Walnut - 17th got home - & thus ended a glorious trip without a flaw on accident --

the mail arrived but no order came - Telegraphed at once to the General & asked orders by telegraph & to delay march until after my Comd was paid - On Wednesday 6 - after a day of anxious suspense - got an order to march as soon as paymaster had paid the Comd 

 On Thursday 10 am the paymaster arrived.  The Comd was paid same afternoon Orders were given for a start today 7th at 8 am 
 Visited paymaster & called on the ladies at night

Cos at Supply had been ordered to hold themselves in readiness to march - A week ago they got orders & started last Monday --

 On Saturday I knew that orders for my move had been issued but had not received them
 Expecting them to arrive by Tuesdays mail I got ready designated the Companies expecting to start on 8th - 
 On Tuesday morning I recd a telegram directing me to march my command as soon as I recd orders by mail - Two hours after

Walnut Ck May 8
General? at 6. assembly & broke camp 6,30.

 Pleasant march though twas very hot after 12 m
 Long shot at an antelope & didn't get him. Bagged 3 ducks - men killed several rattlesnakes - saw a large mtn cat but no shot - 
 Camped where road leaves Walnut - good place
 Wood water & grass -
 Henry Kuling overtook us
 en route to Caldwell
 Replenished my ice -
 Distance 16 miles

Was invited to breakfast by Mrs Wheaton. At 8 am the Comd was formed & marched out of the post not a man being drunk or absent a most remarkable unheard of thing only having been paid yesterday.

 Cool - excellent day for marching. I got breakfast bade all good by - paid all my bills - & started about 10 o clk - overtaking the Comd after a brisk gallop about 2 miles from my camping place -- Only 12 miles today - No water good wood & grass -

Pond Ck - May 10th 80
Cold & very windy morning - started 5.20 am as we had a 20 mile march without water 

 I went ahead in ambulance to look for camping place. No water in Pond Ck - except a few small springs trickling from bank -
 Wrote postals to Julia & to Mother
 Comd came in making distance of 21 miles in 7 hours at an hour ahead of what I expected -- All well & in good condition
 Country all burned up from lack of rain. Nice camp except its want of water. The creek now dry is sometimes half a mile wide - Fred opens tonight at Chicago.

Panther Ck May 9
Off at 6.30. Men marched splendidly.
Very hot day - but cool wind. Inside my tent is now 9 pm stifling - outside it is delightful -

 Boon made some excelent long shots at antelope but did not get one - 
 A mule escaped yesterday afternoon & has evidently started for Missouri  We heard of it tonight beyond Pond Ck & going on the road. Road lovely 
 Fair camp - Distance 20 miles --

Tebyn? go with him Old Tom's head utterly gone - cant put a Comd in camp -- Very nice camp ground. My spot in a grove of large trees -- 

 Terrible storm came up at night fall & still continues - Rain wind & ?sharp? lightning
 I don't know that a lovely grove is the best place after my Pond Creek experience six weeks ago -- Mail at night -- nothing important
 Distance 24 miles

Bluff C. Near Caldwell
May 11, 1880
Broke camp 5.15.
Went ahead in ambulance 
Reached Caldwell or rather Bluff Ck a little after 9. & had a rousing breakfast, or lunch I suppose I ought to call it
Went to Caldwell after  -
Also to camp of I Co.
Very hot day. Commd did not get in until near 3 pm & then very much played out.
Sent Claggete? on to Wellington - & let

On Cars May 13th --
Received last evening by hands of Dr Comfort, telegram from Dept Hdqrs prohibiting my taking any transpn except 6 mule teams & wagons. - Am disgusted - Sent Claggettt into town with telegram

Broke Camp 5.30. went with Wellington ahead of Comd 
 Found a lot of my men who had sneaked into town last night
 Train all waiting for us
 When Comd arrived about 7 am went up with it - put sentinals & N.C. Offs on watch to keep the men from slipping away & went to work - Goods in stores - took wagons to pieces?

Shoo Fly May 12 -
Started early. 5.15. another hard march - A dozen drunkards last night & lots of stragglers or those who would like to straggle -- got five out of jail - Got through town without delay.

 Left Lockwood to bring up all stragglers.
 Camped on head ponds of Shoo Fly. Water poor & no wood - but we brought both with us. Animals drank the creek water eagerly -
 Distance 22 miles
 Dr Comport passed us north to Ft Reno --

Telegram from Dep Hdqrs refusing to let me take my horses but saying there is plenty of transpn at Ft Garland

 Swapped Boon for one of his 6 mule drivers to his great delight & take him along I had to send his ambulance back -
 On Cars May 14 1880

Slept pretty well woke up about Pawnee Rock. Got no breakfast until we arrived at Dodge City 12 m. Stopped here 3 hours & had mules taken out of Cars fed & watered

Saw Bob Wingert & many other old acquaintances

loaded those - then got shoes off my mules - loaded them & finally got all the men on board by 3.30 pm . About 4 we got off - Supper for ourselves & coffee for men at Newton - Mrs Hay left for west & old Julian for east - We are all very comfortable - 3 of Smiths men got away in Wellington & were left. I am not sorry for they were miserable drunken wretches - S's Comp is in a horrible state of discipline - owing to his own bad habits - I had to sit on him very heavily.

Pueblo - May 15th 80

Woke up at daylight after a sleep of 9 solid hours to find that we had made only about 75 miles since I went to bed. Took a lunch breakfast arrived at La Junta 10 am & took another. Country all a parched desert. Improved on our time & finally arrived at Pueblo 3 pm. Found telegrams of no importance Pope passed up yesterday to Garland & is expected to go back tomorrow -
 Got our Compy property transferred to Narrow Guage very soon

The country is absolutely burned up - no rain for a long time & not a green thing to be seen - Maj Affling & wife came to Depot by accident - He is ordered to join me & is all packed & ready  I told him I was going to wait 3 hours & he went off for the Fort at a great rate to get his baggage and join us - As he did not return, I suppose his wife persuaded him to take regular train - Replenished my stock of canned stuff & had a good lunch about six & went to bed at 8 pm - just about Lakin on RR  - Rain storm in evening

Ft Garland May 16, 80
No man who has not tried it can realize the difficulty of getting a good nights rest, on a car of narrow guage -

 I woke up at La Veta, & after a long delay went up the mountain. It is simply impossible to do justice to the scenery & the experiencing? It is the most remarkable work I ever saw. Just over the summit we meet the train going East. On it were Genl Pope & Mackenzie. Had a few moments conversation with Pope who went East

but there was no end of trouble to get cars for men & animals Govt Agent - Rankin - Head RR man very obliging but not extremely? efficient - However he finally got the cars - got supper in town.
Transferred the men about 8.30 pm. & went to bed having been pumped dry by an Interviewer Got coffee for men & had animals taken off car for food & water Have had a tedious but very pleasant trip

Springs. 7 miles from Garland
17th May 1880
Had my wagon loaded up early - a hard thing to cut 2 loads into one & decide just what I must take & must leave. Had to leave my desks but when I told Mackenzie he ordered them to be sent out by first train. Had a great deal to do but got through all, & the Comd started half hour a head of time. I went up to post to see Mc. & write letter to Mother & Julia.

 Finished & caught Comd just as it was about to pass the camping place.
 7 miles

Mackenzie went back with us to Garland. He tells me I must get off tomorro - gives me only one wagon, says I shall not take Laura etc. etc. I know him well however & am not scared. Got my troops in camp Rec'd my orders from Mackenzie & assumed comd. Have 11 comps organized into 3 Batns. - Webb comd 1st. Brady 2d. Offley 3d.

 Lunched with Mackenzie. Got an ambulance & authority to take Joe & Laura. Ordered everything to be ready to march at 2 pm tomorro. Cant find out where we are going nor what we are going for - No letters --

waste of sand & sage brush

 These Springs are a feature
 They are artesian. The water from some high elevation finds outlet here & in course of time has thrown out mud & sand enough to build elevation higher than the general level from the top of which the springs break out. Some of my miserable drunkards who left at Wellington came up this p.m. How they got along the R R is a mystery - I hoped I had lost them. Seven others deserted last night. Our pay system is a persuasion? on desertion

Distance 13 miles.

Washington Springs
18th
5 miles from Alamosa 
Broke camp 6.20 am.

Part of my Comd paid yesterday so I had lots of drunkards lined out: yesterday & Vance on rear guard had a hard time.
 He is a weak man anyhow
 Today there are many big heads, but all are so much improved that the rear guard was up unclear with the wagons
 Beautiful day but very warm.
 Tho' the spring brook on which we camped was frozen this am Our route is through - across the San Louis Park - & a dreary monotonous

Jacksons Ranche -
Wednesday May 19, 80
My 53rd Birth-Day - & by no means a hilarious one but not unpleasant
Broke Camp 6.20 am.
Took ambulance & went into town (Alamosa) bought some necessaries, saw Dorsh about the wood & hay I used yesterday. He says its all right - River very high quite a business little town with many good stores.

 Bought all I needed - Joined Comd before it passed - Camped at Jackson - Short march 11 miles

About 5 pm freight train came by bringing wood & hay - Keeling came in it also -

 St Hay went to town, with telegram to Mackenzie.
  He sent back an orderly with notice that wood & Hay were to be delivered to me as I pass Alamosa  tomorrow. sent orderly back notifying him that I can not take it.
  Miserable sand camp.
  If there had been wind we would have suffered - It is a good omen that the wind has stopped for us here

Mr B came down & invited me to his house which is the more comfortable & best furnished I have seen on the trip -

Filled Hay & I up with beer & invited us to dinner but we had just lunched.
 About 3 pm there came up a furious wind & dust storm. A great many tents were blown down, mine withstood the blast, but was so filled with dust that one could scarcely see anything.
It lasted until after 5 pm 
Now all is calm & peaceful -

Bedells Ranch
Sagarata Ck
Friday May 21, 80
Broke Camp 5.15 am
Road excellent, but we had to make 19 miles without water - The Sagarata a nice creek. Many Ranches bottoms all fenced in & no good camping places.

 Mr Bedell a rich & hospitable man gave me a field to camp in Also got from him wood & some straw - Hay not to be had - Soon after Comd got to camp

Russell Springs
May 22d
Broke Camp 6.15 am
Called on Mr Beadell to thank him & wife for their kindness, & to bid good by - Men somewhat used up by yesterdays march

Took it easy today -
Good road & several streams of water - Camped here at 11. am. Good water - & bought wood & hay - very good camp. Ben Clark came by en route to visit Mackenzie. No news -

Pleasant day. 
Distance 13 miles --

Got a man with measels Ordered Hospl Steward to take him to Rose Camp in ambulance tomorro.

 Beaumont passed us about 2 pm- went into camp on canon? 4 miles beyond. Pack mule train also along camped in next field - 
 Men badly used up today by the long march without water - Mr Bedell gave me a sack of potatoes -
 This is a fine agriculture country. Also a great mining country.
 Distance 23 miles

Upper Crossing

 Saguache Ck

Sunday May 24th
Broke Camp 6 am
Good road & marching except the wind which blew directly in mens faces carrying great clouds of dust making it altogether the worst day we have had.

 I arrived in camp 11 am found Cavy Sergt with hay. Tried fishing couldn't get a bite - hardly stand up for wind - Comd arrived 1 pm 

good camp - Met paymaster
Distance 17 miles -

Near Saguache
pronounced Siwatch
Sunday May 23d
Broke camp 6.10
Rode in in ambulance 
Arrived town 7.30.
Got mail - Letter from James. Mother improving No letter from Julia or Fred. 
Bought many things.
Comd arrived 9.50 -
Rode out ahead & selected camp 2 miles from town 
Beautiful Camp. Went fishing. got 3 trout - Wrote to Mother Julia & Clarke at night --
Distance 10 ½ miles

Cavalry leave tomorro
I next day -- Visited Roses cantonment - He has done a deal of work but not in as ship shape a manner as I like -- Quite busy today -- Mac has kept me going with all sorts of orders. 

Took McMurm my orderly - I took OBrien in his place - & got another man on Hdqt guard 
Very Cold -
Our camp is 10000 feet above the sea
Snow last night -- & last winter snowy not yet all gone about us

Cochetopa pass 
May 25 1880
Courier from Mackenzie last night. In accordance with my request he authorized me to remain over one day either at Creek or at pass -- Creek very tempting - nice camp etc. but I have number of barefooted mules & so moved to this place to have them shod --

Arrived at Mc's Camp 8.30 - had satisfactory talk with him - got all arranged to suit me - 
 Beaumont

taken the Supce Dept with him & my Officers have no supplies -- wrote to wife & Mother --

At night wrote to Cop - Northing new -- pleasant day but cool ---

We have been constantly on the move 19 days without a rest or break. Fonero is our first days rest - & wish it will close what I consider the first chapter of this expedition --

 Scenery today very wild & beautiful _ roads very bad -
 Distance 8 miles --
 Had a glorious hot bath & for the first time a stove in my tent-

Back Cover - Mottled, dark rust color
